00001 /* Matthew Hammer <hammer@tti-c.org> */
00002 
00003 /* S-Destinations -- Can sometimes be a more stable alternative to
00004    write-once modrefs as destinations.  The main use is within
00005    recursive functions where a given incoming destination isn't
00006    written on every iteration.
00007    
00008    An S-dest acts as a proxy for the destination (modref) it currently
00009    holds and it's assumed that each destination will be replaced once
00010    its written--but this isn't necessary.  Once a s-dest is created
00011    for a given destination (modref) it can be written in one of two
00012    ways.  The operation [next] writes this destination and replaces it
00013    with a new given destination.  The operation [done] is similar to
00014    [next] except that it doesn't replace the current destination.
00015 */
00016 
00017 #ifndef __SDEST_H__
00018 #define __SDEST_H__
00019 
00020 #include "ceal.h"
00021 
00022 typedef struct sdest_s {
00023   modref_t* sdest[0];
00024   modref_t  sdest_modref;
00025 } sdest_t;
00026 
00027 sdest_t* Sdest(modref_t* dest);
00028 sdest_t* sdest_next(sdest_t* sdest, void* value, modref_t* dest);
00029 void     sdest_done(sdest_t* sdest, void* value);
00030 
00031 #endif
